Usage Patterns of the interpret() Function

Matthias Kloft

2025-11-11

Source: vignettes/articles/02-Usage_Patterns.qmd

Overview

This document demonstrates the different usage patterns for interpret(). The interpret() function is the main function of the psychinterpreter package and can be used in multiple ways. It will automatically detect the type of input provided and run the appropriate method for interpretation.

Setup

Packages

Code
packages <- c(
  "psychinterpreter",
  "ellmer",
  "ollamar",
  "psych",
  "lavaan",
  "mirt",
  "dplyr",
  "here",
  "DT",
  "pander"
)
# Load required packages using pacman
if (!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman")
Loading required package: pacman
Code
pacman::p_load(char = packages)

LLM Setup

We use Ollama, so we need to make sure to start the server before running this.

Code
#!/bin/bash

# Check if port 11434 (default Ollama port) is in use
if netstat -ano | grep 11434 > /dev/null; then
    echo "Ollama is already running."
else
    echo "Starting Ollama..."
    ollama serve
fi
Ollama is already running.

Test the connection:

Code
system2("ollama serve", wait = FALSE)
Warning in system2("ollama serve", wait = FALSE): '"ollama serve"' not found
Code
# test the connection to the Ollama server
ollamar::test_connection()
Ollama local server running
<httr2_response>
GET http://localhost:11434/
Status: 200 OK
Content-Type: text/plain
Body: In memory (17 bytes)

We will use the model “gpt-oss:20b-cloud”, which needs to be installed. Since this is a cloud-powered model, you need an account with Ollama and be logged in to run this model.

Code
# pull the model from ollama if it is not already installed
if (!"gpt-oss:20b-cloud" %in% ollamar::list_models()$name) {
  ollamar::pull("gpt-oss:20b-cloud")
}

Run Factor Analysis

Code
fa_model <- fa(mtcars[,1:4], nfactors = 2, rotate = "oblimin")

var_info <- data.frame(
  variable = c("mpg", "cyl", "disp", "hp"),
  description = c("Miles per gallon", "Cylinders", "Displacement", "Horsepower")
)

Usage Patterns

Pattern 1: Fitted Model Object

Automatically extracts model components from fitted objects.

Code
interpret(
  fit_results = fa_model,
  variable_info = var_info,
  provider = "ollama",
  model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud",
  word_limit = 50
)
ℹ Starting fa interpretation...
ℹ Creating temporary chat session...
ℹ Building prompt...
ℹ Querying LLM...
ℹ Parsing LLM response...
ℹ Creating diagnostics...
ℹ Building report...
✔ Interpretation complete!

FACTOR ANALYSIS INTERPRETATION
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Number of factors: 2
Loading cutoff: 0.3
LLM used: ollama - gpt-oss:20b-cloud
Elapsed time: 14.6

SUGGESTED FACTOR NAMES
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

• Factor 1 (84%): Engine Power Index
• Factor 2 (1.7%): Residual Engine Variation (n.s.)

Total variance explained: 85.7%

FACTOR CORRELATIONS
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

MR1: MR2 = .03
MR2: MR1 = .03

DETAILED FACTOR INTERPRETATIONS
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Factor 1 (MR1) - Engine Power Index
Number of significant loadings: 4
Variance explained: 84.03%
Factor Correlations: MR2 = .03

Variables:
  1. disp, Displacement (, , .955)
  2. cyl, Cylinders (, , .953)
  3. mpg, Miles per gallon (, , -.893)
  4. hp, Horsepower (, , .862)

LLM Interpretation:
This factor captures engine dimension and performance, loading heavily on cylinders, displacement, horsepower and
inversely on miles‑per‑gallon. It represents overall engine size and power, explaining 84 % of variance and
distinguishing larger, high‑power engines from efficient models. This factor is instrumental in engine design
optimization and vehicle classification.

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

Factor 2 (MR2) - Residual Engine Variation (n.s.)
Number of significant loadings: 0
Variance explained: 1.7%
Factor Correlations: MR1 = .03

WARNING: No variables load above cutoff (0.3). Emergency rule applied: using top 2 variable(s) below cutoff for
interpretation.

Variables:
  1. hp, Horsepower (, , .195)
  2. disp, Displacement (, , -.172)

LLM Interpretation:
This residual factor, featuring weak loadings on horsepower and displacement only, captures minimal variance (1.7 %). It
likely represents measurement noise or unmodeled small‑scale engine differences, lacking substantive meaning or strong
relationships to the primary engine factor. Hence, it receives no substantive emphasis in model reporting.

or unmodeled small‑scale engine differences, lacking substantive meaning or
strong relationships to the primary engine factor. Hence, it receives no
substantive emphasis in model reporting.

Pattern 2: Structured List

For custom data structures or manual extraction.

For FA, provide loadings (required) and optionally factor_cor_mat:

Code
loadings_matrix <- fa_model$loadings
factor_cor_mat <- fa_model$Phi

interpret(
  fit_results = list(loadings = loadings_matrix, factor_cor_mat = factor_cor_mat),
  variable_info = var_info,
  model_type = "fa",
  provider = "ollama",
  model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud",
  word_limit = 50
)
ℹ Starting fa interpretation...
ℹ Creating temporary chat session...
ℹ Building prompt...
ℹ Querying LLM...
ℹ Parsing LLM response...
ℹ Creating diagnostics...
ℹ Building report...
✔ Interpretation complete!

FACTOR ANALYSIS INTERPRETATION
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Number of factors: 2
Loading cutoff: 0.3
LLM used: ollama - gpt-oss:20b-cloud
Elapsed time: 6.73

SUGGESTED FACTOR NAMES
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

• Factor 1 (84%): High Power / Low Fuel Efficiency
• Factor 2 (1.7%): Residual Variation (n.s.)

Total variance explained: 85.7%

FACTOR CORRELATIONS
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

MR1: MR2 = .03
MR2: MR1 = .03

DETAILED FACTOR INTERPRETATIONS
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Factor 1 (MR1) - High Power / Low Fuel Efficiency
Number of significant loadings: 4
Variance explained: 84.03%
Factor Correlations: MR2 = .03

Variables:
  1. disp, Displacement (, , .955)
  2. cyl, Cylinders (, , .953)
  3. mpg, Miles per gallon (, , -.893)
  4. hp, Horsepower (, , .862)

LLM Interpretation:
MR1 represents vehicle power characteristics that drive higher horsepower, larger engine displacement, and more
cylinders, all of which inversely affect fuel economy. The strong loadings indicate a common underlying construct of
high-performance engines, giving MR1 nearly 84 % of total variance.

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

Factor 2 (MR2) - Residual Variation (n.s.)
Number of significant loadings: 0
Variance explained: 1.7%
Factor Correlations: MR1 = .03

WARNING: No variables load above cutoff (0.3). Emergency rule applied: using top 2 variable(s) below cutoff for
interpretation.

Variables:
  1. hp, Horsepower (, , .195)
  2. disp, Displacement (, , -.172)

LLM Interpretation:
MR2 aggregates negligible loadings across all variables, showing almost no coherent pattern. Its 1.7 % variance
contribution and near-zero correlation with MR1 suggest it captures measurement noise or minor idiosyncratic factors
unrelated to the main power–efficiency construct and offers no substantive insight into vehicle characteristics.

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

• Factor 2 (1.7%): Residual Variation (n.s.)

  4. hp, Horsepower (, , .862)

  1. hp, Horsepower (, , .195)
  2. disp, Displacement (, , -.172)

LLM Interpretation:
MR2 aggregates negligible loadings across all variables, showing almost no
coherent pattern. Its 1.7 % variance contribution and near-zero correlation with
MR1 suggest it captures measurement noise or minor idiosyncratic factors
unrelated to the main power–efficiency construct and offers no substantive
insight into vehicle characteristics.

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

Pattern 3: Chat Session (Token-Efficient)

Reuse chat session across analyses to save tokens.

Code
chat <- chat_session(model_type = "fa",
                     provider = "ollama",
                     model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud")
result1 <- interpret(
  chat_session = chat,
  fit_results = fa_model,
  variable_info = var_info,
  word_limit = 50,
  silent = 1
)
ℹ Starting fa interpretation...
ℹ Building prompt...
ℹ Querying LLM...
ℹ Parsing LLM response...
ℹ Creating diagnostics...
ℹ Building report...
✔ Interpretation complete!
Code
result2 <- interpret(
  chat_session = chat,
  fit_results = list(loadings = loadings_matrix, factor_cor_mat = factor_cor_mat),
  variable_info = var_info,
  word_limit = 50,
  silent = 1
)
ℹ Starting fa interpretation...
ℹ Building prompt...
ℹ Querying LLM...
ℹ Parsing LLM response...
ℹ Creating diagnostics...
ℹ Building report...
✔ Interpretation complete!

We can check the total global token usage:

Code
print(chat)
Factor Analysis Chat Session
Provider: ollama
Model: gpt-oss:20b-cloud
Created: 2025-11-11 17:56:50.480465
Interpretations run: 2
Total tokens - Input: 1652 , Output: 2832
